importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication reflects the ongoing federal government shutdown and the immediate risk of food stamp benefits ending in November 2025.
The federal government shutdown began on October 1, 2025, which triggered the funding crisis affecting SNAP and other nutrition programs.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The food stamp program is at risk of running out of funds by the beginning of November 2025, with benefits set to be suspended or partially paid if no action is taken.

keyTakeAways: Roughly 42 million Americans are at risk of losing food stamp benefits in November due to the federal government shutdown.
The USDA has warned that food stamp funding will be depleted in two weeks, and states are being asked to pause November payments until further notice.
The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), known as food stamps, provides an average monthly benefit of $188 per person.
A $6 billion contingency fund exists, but it is insufficient to cover the projected $8 billion in November benefits.
17 states have halted new food stamp applications because their systems require partial payments that cannot be processed during the funding gap.
The Trump administration previously used $300 million in tariff revenue to keep WIC running, but that funding is not available for SNAP.
Democrats and state officials, including New York Governor Kathy Hochul, criticize the administration for prioritizing political agendas over food security.
The shutdown is part of a broader political impasse between Republicans and Democrats over a federal spending package.
The food stamp program is a key part of the nationâ€™s safety net, especially critical during Thanksgiving season when food needs rise.
Advocacy groups urge the administration to act urgently, as previous shutdowns have resulted in critical aid lapses.

namedEntities.name: Brooke Rollins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is central to the administration's response to the SNAP funding crisis, publicly stating that the shutdown is hurting vulnerable families and blaming Democrats for political agenda over food security.

namedEntities.name: Kathy Hochul
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She criticized the Trump administration for halting food stamp benefits, calling it an unprecedented and harmful move that puts vulnerable families at risk.

namedEntities.name: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the largest and most critical safety net programs, with millions of Americans relying on it for food access, especially as Thanksgiving approaches.

namedEntities.name: WIC
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Women, Infants, and Children nutrition program
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It has been temporarily protected with tariff revenue, but that funding is not sufficient to cover SNAP, showing the broader strain on nutrition assistance programs.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is directly responsible for the funding decisions that have affected SNAP and WIC, including shifting tariff revenue to WIC and failing to fund SNAP in November.

namedEntities.name: Democrats
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are accused by the Trump administration of prioritizing political agendas over food security, and they counter that Republicans are unwilling to negotiate a spending deal.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is responsible for managing SNAP and communicating funding shortfalls to states, and its decision to halt payments has directly impacted access to food for millions.

namedEntities.name: New York
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the states affected, with Governor Hochul leading criticism of federal policy decisions that endanger food access for vulnerable families.

namedEntities.name: Obamacare premium subsidies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Democrats argue the Republican refusal to extend these subsidies is part of a broader political impasse that contributes to the shutdown and its impact on food assistance.

namedEntities.name: Tariff revenue
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was used to keep WIC running, but not sufficient to fund SNAP, highlighting the limited capacity of emergency funds in addressing multiple programs.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amid an ongoing federal government shutdown beginning on October 1, 2025, the U.S. Department of Agriculture warns that the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), or food stamps, will run out of funds by November, leaving approximately 42 million Americans at risk of losing food assistance. The administration has not committed to partial payments, and 17 states have suspended new applications due to system limitations. The Trump administration blames Democrats for political obstruction, while state officials and advocacy groups criticize the decision as a threat to food security, especially as Thanksgiving approaches. Although a $6 billion contingency fund exists, it is insufficient to cover the projected $8 billion in November benefits. Unlike WIC, which was temporarily protected with $300 million in tariff revenue, SNAP lacks such resources. Experts and advocates stress that this is a critical moment, as food pantries are already strained and vulnerable families face hunger without timely aid.
title: Millions of Americans at Risk of Losing Food Stamps Amid Shutdown
